title: 113_hr5778
content: The Act may be cited as the "Boko Haram Disarmament and Northeast Nigeria Recovery Act of 2014". Key findings are also included in the Act. Congress makes findings regarding the abduction of 276 female students by Boko Haram from a school in Nigeria, the closure of schools due to attacks, and the threat of selling the kidnapped girls into slavery. Boko Haram has targeted schools, mosques, churches, villages, and government facilities in northern Nigeria to create an Islamic state. The group has killed over 4,000 people since 2011 and poses a threat to US interests in the region. There is a possibility that the abducted girls may have been taken to neighboring countries. The United States deployed military personnel to Chad to locate kidnapped schoolgirls and support counter-terrorism efforts in the Sahel region. Cameroon, Niger, and Chad also deployed troops to secure borders against Boko Haram. The US designated Boko Haram as a Foreign Terrorist Organization in 2013. In May 2014, Boko Haram was added to the UN sanctions list for terrorist organizations. The US Senate and House passed resolutions condemning Boko Haram for abducting female students in Nigeria. The United States aims to resolve the conflict in northeast Nigeria and Boko Haram-affected areas by eliminating the threat posed by Boko Haram, rescuing abducted individuals, and supporting reconstruction and reconciliation efforts. A regional strategy for defeating Boko Haram is required. The President must develop a regional strategy within 90 days to support efforts against Boko Haram, protect civilians, and enforce the rule of law. The strategy should include plans to rescue kidnapping victims, protect civilians, and coordinate diplomatic, economic, and intelligence efforts. The President must develop a regional strategy within 90 days to support efforts against Boko Haram, including diplomatic, economic, intelligence, development, humanitarian, law enforcement, and military elements. The strategy should also include a framework to evaluate progress and effectiveness, and may include a classified annex. SEC. 5. Humanitarian assistance for areas affected by Boko Haram. The President is authorized to provide humanitarian and development assistance to populations affected by Boko Haram. Funds received by the US Government from a specific case will be made available for this purpose. The President is authorized to provide humanitarian and development assistance to populations affected by Boko Haram. Funds received from a specific case will be used for this purpose, including Islands, interests, benefits, or assets related to the case. SEC. 6. ASSISTANCE FOR RECOVERY AND RECONSTRUCTION IN AREAS AFFECTED BY BOKO HARAM. The sense of Congress is for the President to support efforts in Boko Haram-affected areas and Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger to assist displaced people, improve governance, and provide quality education. The sense of Congress is to support efforts in Boko Haram-affected areas and Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger to assist displaced people, improve governance, provide quality education, strengthen civilian police capacity in Nigeria, prevent crime and violence, address gender-based violence, promote programs for physical harm and trauma, and increase assistance if the Government of Nigeria shows commitment to transparency and accountability in reconstruction. The United States demonstrates commitment to transparent and accountable reconstruction in Boko Haram-affected areas of Nigeria by increasing oversight activities, committing substantial funds, and coordinating with other donor nations to strengthen accountability mechanisms for recovery efforts. The sense of Congress is that bilateral assistance to Nigeria should be withheld if the Government is not committed to transparent and accountable reconstruction in Boko Haram-affected areas. SEC. 7. REPORT. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the strategy submission, detailing progress on implementation and evaluating assistance provided under the Act. The report must include actions taken, assistance descriptions, evaluations of bilateral aid to Nigeria, and the amounts of assistance committed. The report to Congress must detail progress on implementation and evaluate assistance provided under the Act, including actions taken, assistance descriptions, evaluations of bilateral aid to Nigeria, and amounts of assistance committed. It should also include a description of assistance amounts provided to Nigeria by the Government, donor countries, and relevant organizations. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate.
